206.01 WARDS ESTABLISHED.
   In accordance with Ohio R.C. 703.06 and 731.06 and the proclamation of the
Secretary of State filed with Council on February 6, 1911, and placed on file
in the records of Council, the territory included in the City is hereby divided
into four wards, which wards shall be known and bounded as follows:
   (a)   The First Ward includes all of the territory lying north of the
centerline of Main Street and west of the centerline of Chestnut Street.
   (b)   The Second Ward includes all of the territory lying north of the
centerline of Main Street and east of the centerline of Chestnut Street.
   (c)   The Third Ward includes all of the territory lying south of the
centerline of Main Street and west of the centerline of Chestnut Street and of
the centerline of Chestnut Street extended south from Lake Street to the south
corporate line.
   (d)   The Fourth Ward includes all of the territory lying south of the
centerline of Main Street and east of the centerline of Chestnut Street and of
the centerline of Chestnut Street extended south from Lake Street to the south
corporate line.
(1972 Code §105.01)
CHAPTER 208
Open Meetings
208.01   Purpose.
208.02   Application of chapter.
208.03   Definitions.
208.04   Meetings of Council.
208.05   Notice of regular and organizational meetings.
208.06   Notice of special meetings.
208.07   Notice to news media of special meetings; emergency meetings.
208.08   Notification of discussion of specific types of public business.
208.09   Obtaining information from Clerk; certification of compliance.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Council meetings - see CHTR. Art.
X, §§
5,
6,
10;
220.01 et seq.
Open meetings - see Ohio R.C. 121.22
Disturbing a lawful meeting - see GEN. OFF.
648.05
Meetings of the Planning and Zoning Commission - see P. & Z.
1220.02,
1220.03
Meetings of the Board of Zoning Appeals - see P. & Z.
1264.03 et seq.
 
208.01 PURPOSE.
   Council hereby adopts the following rules, pursuant to Ohio R.C. 121.22, for
the purpose of:
   (a)   Establishing a reasonable method for any person to determine the time
and place of all regularly scheduled meetings of Council and other decision-
making bodies of the City over which Council has jurisdiction;
   (b)   Making provisions for giving advance notice of special meetings to the
news media that have requested notification; and
   (c)   Making provision for persons to request and obtain reasonable advance
notification of all meetings at which any specific type of public business is
to be discussed.
   The rules established in this chapter are in addition to any applicable
requirements that may have been established by resolution of a body as to
notice of special meetings to members of that body.
(Ord. 2016-111. Passed 8-1-16.)
208.02 APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   The rules established in this chapter shall be applicable to Council and to
each decision- making body over which Council has jurisdiction or as to which
Council is authorized by laws to establish rules pursuant to Ohio R.C. 121.22.
(Ord. 2016-111. Passed 8-1-16.)
208.03 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   “Body” means Council, each decision-making body of the City for which
Council has the authority to establish rules fo procedure, and each decision-
making body of the City which as authority to establish its own rules of
procedure and which, by resolution, either adopts this chapter in full or
incorporates it by reference, including, in each case, committees composed of
members of the body or another decision-making entity of such body.
   (b)   “City” means the City of Ravenna, Ohio.
   (c)   “Clerk” means, in the case of the City, the Clerk of Council and, in
the case of each other body, the clerk, secretary or other officer of that body
having custody of the records of such body.
   (d)   "Meeting" means any prearranged discussion of the public business of
the Municipal body by a majority of the members of the Municipal body.
   (e)   "Oral notification" means notification given orally either in person
or by telephone directly to the person for whom such notification is intended
or by leaving an oral message with such per-son at the address, or, if by
telephone, at the telephone number or numbers, of such person as shown on the
records kept by the Clerk under this chapter.
   (f)   "Post" means to post on the bulletin board located on the first floor
of the City Hall, which area is accessible to the public during the usual
business hours of the City Hall.
   (g)   "Special meeting" means a meeting which is neither a regular meeting
nor an adjournment of a regular or special meeting to another time or day to
consider items specifically stated on the original agenda of such regular or
special meeting.
   (h)   "Written notification" means notification in writing mailed,
telegraphed or delivered to the address of the person for whom such
notification is intended, as shown on the records kept by the Clerk under this
chapter, or in any way delivered to such person. If mailed, such notification
shall be mailed by postage prepaid, first class mail, deposited in a United
States postal service mailbox no later than the second day preceding the day of
the meeting to which such notification refers, provided that at least one
regular mail delivery day for both commercial establishments and resi-dences
falls between the day of mailing and the day of such meeting.
      (Ord. 2016-111. Passed 8-1-16.)
208.04 MEETINGS OF COUNCIL.
   (a)    Regular meetings of Council shall be held on the first Monday of each
month except for legal holidays and days on which a quorum of Council will not
be available. Committee of the Whole shall hold Work Sessions on the second to
last Monday of each month except for legal holidays and days on which a quorum
of Council will not be available. Written notice of days on which regular
meetings of Council will not be held shall be posted. Regular meetings and work
sessions of Council will commence at 7:00 p.m. in the Council Chambers of the
City Hall.
 
   (b)   Regular meetings of any other body shall be established by resolution
of that body or as heretofore established by such body.
(Ord. 2016-111. Passed 8-1-16.)
208.05 NOTICE OF REGULAR AND ORGANIZATIONAL MEETINGS.
   (a)   The Clerk shall post a statement of the times and places of regular
meetings of a body for each calendar year not later than the second day
preceding the day of the first regular meeting (other than the organizational
meeting) of the calendar year of the body. The Clerk shall check at reasonable
intervals to ensure that such statement remains so posted during the calendar
year. If at any time during the calendar year the time or place of regular
meetings, or of any one regular meeting, is changed on a permanent or temporary
basis, a statement of the time and place of such changed regular meeting or
meetings shall be so posted by the Clerk at least twenty-four hours before the
time of the changed regular meeting or the first of the changed regular
meetings in accordance with Ohio Revised Code Section 121.22(b)(1).
 
   (b)   The Clerk shall post a statement of the time and place of any
organizational meeting of a body at least twenty-four hours before the time of
such organizational meeting.
(Ord. 2016-111. Passed 8-1-16.)
208.06 NOTICE OF SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   (a)   Except in the case of a special meeting referred to in Section
208.07(a) through (d), the Clerk shall, no later than twenty-four hours before
the time of a special meeting of the body, post a statement of the time, place
and purposes of such special meeting.
 
   (b)   The statement under Section
208.05(b) and subsection (a) hereof, and the notifications under Section
208.07(a) through (d), shall state such specific or general purposes then known
to the Clerk to be intended to be considered at such special meeting in
accordance with Ohio Revised Code Section 121.22(1)(b).
(Ord. 2016-111. Passed 8-1-16.)
208.07 NOTICE TO NEWS MEDIA OF SPECIAL MEETINGS; EMERGENCY MEETINGS.
   (a) Any news medium organization that desires to be given advance
notification of special meetings of a body shall file with the Clerk a written
request therefor.
   (b) Except in the event of an emergency requiring immediate official action
as referred to in subsection (f) hereof, a special meeting shall not be held
unless at least twenty- four hours advance notice of the time, place and
purpose of such special meeting is given to the news media that have requested
such advance notification in accordance with this section.
 
   (c)   News media requests for such advance notification of special meetings
shall specify the body that is the subject of such request, the name of the
medium, the name and email address of the person to whom written notifications
to the medium may be email.
 
   (d)   Any such request shall be effective during the calendar year in which
it is delivered to the Clerk or for the next succeeding calendar year if it is
delivered in the months of November or December. Each requesting news medium
shall be informed of such period of effectiveness at the time it files its
request. Such requests may be modified or extended only by filing a new request
with the Clerk. A request shall not be deemed to be made unless it specifies
all of the information required by this chapter, and such request may be
conclusively relied upon by the body that is the subject of such request and by
the Clerk.
 
   (e)   The Clerk shall give such notification to the news media that have
requested such advance notification in accordance with subsection (c) hereof,
of the time, place and purposes of each special meeting, at least twenty-four
hours prior to the time of such special meeting.
 
    (f)   In the event of an emergency requiring immediate official action, a
special meeting of the body may be held without giving twenty-four hours
advance notification thereof to the requesting news media. The persons calling
such meeting, or any one or more of such persons or the Clerk on their behalf,
shall immediately give oral notification or written notification, or both, as
the person or persons giving such notification determine, of the time, place
and purposes of such spe-cial meeting to such news media that have requested
such advance notification in accordance with subsection (c) hereof. The minutes
or the call, or both, of any such special meeting shall state the general
nature of the emergency requiring immediate official action.
(Ord. 2016-111. Passed 8-1-16.)
208.08 NOTIFICATION OF DISCUSSION OF SPECIFIC TYPES OF PUBLIC BUSINESS.
   (a) Any person, upon written request as provided herein, may obtain
reasonable advance noti-fication of all meetings at which any specific type of
public business is scheduled to be discussed.
 
   (b)   Such person may file a written or oral request with the Clerk
specifying the person's name and email address. Such request may be canceled by
written request from such person to the Clerk.
   (c)   The Clerk shall, if possible, give such advance notification under
this section by written notification. If such written notification cannot be
given or has not been given, the Clerk shall give oral notification.
   (d)   The contents of written notification under this section may be a copy
of the agenda of the meeting. Written notification under this section may be
accomplished by giving advance written notification, by copies of the agenda,
of all meetings of the body that is the subject of such re-quest.
(Ord. 2016-111. Passed 8-1-16.)
208.09 OBTAINING INFORMATION FROM CLERK; CERTIFICATION OF COMPLIANCE.
   (a)   Any person may visit or telephone the office of the Clerk during the
regular office hours of the office in question to determine, based on
information available at the office: the time and place of regular meetings;
the time, place and purposes of any then known special meetings; and whether
the then available agenda of any such future meeting states that any specific
type of pub-lic business, identified by such person, is to be discussed at such
meeting.
 
   (b)   Any notification provided in this chapter to be given by the Clerk may
be given by any person acting in behalf of or under the authority of the Clerk.
 
   (c) The Clerk shall maintain a record of the date and manner, and time if
pertinent under this chapter, of all actions taken with regard to notices and
notifications under this chapter.
(Ord. 2016-111. Passed 8-1-16.)
CHAPTER 210
Public Improvements
210.01   Alternative bidding procedure.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Public improvements - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 153
Streets generally - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
1020
Sidewalks, curbs and street lawns - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
1022
Improvements in subdivisions - see P. & Z. Ch.
1246,
1248.04(j)
 
210.01 ALTERNATIVE BIDDING PROCEDURE.
   Council hereby authorizes that the specifications for competitive bidding
for public improvements contain an alternative method for bidding which allows
a general or prime contractor to submit a bid containing subcontractors' bids
for each separate and distinct trade or kind of mechanical labor, employment or
business involved in the improvement. The purpose of this section is to provide
an alternative method of contracting for public improvements, as set forth in
Ohio R.C. 153.50 et seq., by not requiring a mandatory contract with each
separate and distinct trade or kind of mechanical labor, employment or
business.
(Ord. 1987-133. Passed 12-7-87.)
CHAPTER 212
Public Records
212.01   Definitions.
212.02   Inspection of public records.
212.03   Fees for services.
212.04   Deposit required.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Records Commission - see Ohio R.C. 149.39; ADM. Ch.
284
Availability of public records - see Ohio R.C. 149.43
Tampering with records - see GEN. OFF.
672.15
 
212.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   Confidential law enforcement investigatory record means any record
that pertains to a law enforcement matter of a criminal, quasicriminal, civil
or administrative nature, but only to the extent that the release of the record
would create a high probability of disclosure of any of the following:
      (1)   The identity of a suspect who has not been charged with the offense
to which the record pertains or of an information source or witness to whom
confidentiality has been reasonably promised;
      (2)   Information provided by an information source or witness to whom
confidentiality has been reasonably promised, which information would
reasonably tend to disclose his or her identity;
      (3)   Specific confidential investigatory techniques or procedures or a
specific investigatory work product; or
      (4)   Information that would endanger the life or physical safety of law
enforcement personnel, a crime victim, a witness or a confidential information
source.
   (b)   Medical record means any document or combination of documents, except
those pertaining to births, deaths and the fact of admission to or discharge
from a hospital, that pertains to the medical history, diagnosis, prognosis or
medical condition of a patient and that is generated and maintained in the
process of medical treatment.
   (c)   Public record means any record that is kept by the City, except
medical records, records pertaining to adoption, probation and parole
proceedings, records pertaining to actions under Ohio R.C. 2151.85 and to
appeals of actions arising under that section, records listed in Ohio R.C.
3107.42(A), trial preparation records, confidential law enforcement
investigatory records and records the release of which is prohibited by State
or Federal law.
   (d)   Trial preparation record means any record that contains information
that is specifically compiled in reasonable anticipation of, or in defense of,
a civil or criminal action or proceeding, including the independent thought
processes and personal trial preparation of an attorney.
      (Ord. 1990-31. Passed 3-19-90.)
212.02 INSPECTION OF PUBLIC RECORDS.
   All public records as defined in Section
212.01 shall be promptly prepared and made available for inspection to any
person at all reasonable times during normal business hours. Upon request, a
person responsible for public records shall make copies available at the cost
set forth in Sections
212.03 and
244.07.
(Ord. 1990-31. Passed 3-19-90.)
212.03 FEES FOR SERVICES.
   (a)   Except as provided in Section
242.03 and subsection (b) hereof, the following fees shall be charged and
collected for services rendered in producing requested copies of public records
when such services are rendered to other than law enforcement officials of the
City or County, agents of the Department of Justice of the United States or any
official agency of the United States, any military organization of the United
States or any police agency of any political subdivision:
      (1)   For an uncertified copy of a public record, one dollar ($1.00) for
each page; and
      (2)   For a certified copy of a public record, two dollars ($2.00) for
each page.
   (b)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to copies of public
records furnished to an accused or his or her legal counsel, in connection with
a criminal case, pursuant to Rule 16 of the Ohio Rules of Criminal Procedure.
(Ord. 1990-31. Passed 3-19-90.)
212.04 DEPOSIT REQUIRED.
   (a)   A single request for more than ten copies of public records shall be
accompanied by an advance deposit in the amount of fifty percent of the total
amount due for such copies.
   (b)   If, at the time a request is made, the exact number of copies of
public records to be provided cannot be determined by the person responsible
for providing the copies, the number shall be estimated by that person and an
advance deposit in the amount of fifty percent of the estimated cost of copying
shall be required.
(Ord. 1990-31. Passed 3-19-90.)

214.01 POLICY FOR PURCHASES OVER $25,000.
   (a)   If and to the extent budgeted by Council, the Mayor or a department
head may make purchases and enter into contracts on behalf of the City
involving expenditures of not more than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000).
Council shall approve any such item beyond this authority via an ordinance. In
the case of an emergency the Mayor has the authority to enter into a contract
beyond the amount established above if an emergency exists which affects the
public health, safety or welfare. At the next regularly scheduled Council
meeting such emergency expenditure must be approved by ordinance. Additionally,
the Ohio Revised Code requires formal bidding requirements for certain
expenditures, and in these cases the City will follow all procedures required
by law. In all cases not requiring Council approval, funds used for the
purchase will have been budgeted and the purchase shall follow all normal
purchasing and approval procedures and the Director of Finance shall certify
the availability of funds.
   (b)   Each month, prior to the regular meeting of Council, the Finance
Director will prepare a report listing all of the purchases and contracts
subject to this section, not requiring approval from Council, executed since
the prior month's report.
(Ord. 1998-124. Passed 6-1-98; Ord. 2023-123. Passed 12-4-23.)
214.05 GRANT POLICY.
   (a)   Purpose and Scope.
      (1)   This policy establishes procedures for the grant application
process, detailing criteria for exemptions from Council approval unless
specific conditions require it. It aims to streamline administrative processes,
enhance transparency, and define accountability while ensuring Council
involvement only when necessary.
      (2)   This policy applies to all departments within the City that seek
external funding through grants. It defines when a formal application or an
ordinance is required for a grant.
   (b)   Policy Provisions. Management is permitted to apply for grants without
prior City Council approval, provided that the following conditions are met:
      (1)   Ordinance requirement. Council approval will be sought only if the
grant terms explicitly require approval through an ordinance.
      (2)   Matching funds.
         A.   Department heads applying for grants must verify fund
availability beforehand.
         B.   If a grant requires matching City funds, the Mayor will determine
if formal Council action is necessary before granting final authorization. The
Mayor, in consultation with the Finance Director, will confirm fund
availability and retain final discretion on the decision.
      (3)   Significant conditions. For grants imposing substantial obligations
or terms affecting City resources, programs, or policies, approval must be
obtained from the department head, Mayor, and Finance Director prior to
proceeding.
   (c)   Requirements.
      (1)   The Mayor, as the authorized City signatory, is required to sign
all grant applications.
      (2)   All grants shall require ordinance to allow the Mayor to accept a
grant if awarded.
   (d)   Internal Accountability. To maintain accountability, the City commits
to the following:
      (1)   The grant application will be presented to the Council at the next
available meeting or as soon as feasible with monthly reports.
      (2)   Grant status of acceptance or denial will be given to the Mayor/
Finance Department when available.
   (e)   Review and Amendments. This grant policy may be reviewed to assess its
impact and effectiveness, with adjustments made as necessary due to changes in
grant requirements, government rules or legal requirements.
   (f)   Implementation and Enforcement. This policy shall take effect on
December 2, 2024. Implementation will be led by the Mayor and Finance Office
and will provide guidance to ensure consistent application across all
departments.
(Ord. 2024-153. Passed 12-2-24.)

220.001 CLERK OF COUNCIL.
   There is hereby established in and for the City the full-time position Clerk
of Council.
(Ord. 1996-202. Passed 1-6-96.)
220.01 REGULAR MEETINGS.
   Council shall hold regular meetings on the first Monday of each month at 6:
00 p.m. in the Council Chambers in the Ravenna City Building, but may adjourn a
regular meeting to any other day of the month when public business requires.
When the day fixed for any regular meeting falls upon a legal holiday, the
meeting shall be held at the same hour on the next succeeding day which is not
a holiday.
(Ord. 2016-112. Passed 8-1-16; Ord. 2022-031. Passed 3-7-22.)
220.02 SPECIAL MEETINGS; NOTICE.
   The notice of a special meeting required to be given by Article X,
Section 6, of the Charter shall be served by the Clerk of Council and shall
state the place, hour and purpose of the meeting.
(Ord. 2016-112. Passed 8-1-16.)
220.03 STANDING COMMITTEES.
   The standing committees of Council are Committee of the Whole, Utilities,
Planning, Streets and Sidewalks, Public Health and Safety, Personnel, Community
and Economic Development and Infonnation Systems. Each committee shall consist
of three members, one of whom shall be the chairperson, and a majority of whom
shall constitute a quorum, appointed by the President of Council, subject to
the approval of a majority thereof. However, if a quorum of the members of the
standing committee are not present at a meeting, those members of Council, who
might be present, may serve, on a temporary basis, during the course of that
meeting to create a quorum for the committee, allowing the committee to conduct
the normal business of the committee and move forward with the committee's
agenda.
(Ord. 2016-112. Passed 8-1-16; Ord. 2024-154. Passed 12-2-24.)
220.04 SPECIAL COMMITTEES.
   Special committees may be appointed by the President of Council when, in his
or her opinion, public business requires it, or at the direction of Council,
subject to the approval of a majority of Council.
(Ord. 2016-112. Passed 8-1-16.)
220.05 EXPULSION OF 220.05EXPULSION OF MEMBERS FROM MEETINGS.
   Council may, by a concurring vote of two-thirds of its members, expel any
member from any regular or special meeting of Council, or a meeting of the
Committee of the Whole, for disorderly conduct or a violation of its rules.
(Ord. 2016-112. Passed 8-1-16.)
220.06 POWERS OF PRESIDENT; APPEALS TO COUNCIL.
   The President of Council shall preserve order in all meetings and shall
confine members to the question in debate. He or she may, in common with any
other member of Council, call any member to order who violates any of the
rules, and he or she shall decide all questions of order, subject to appeal to
Council on the demand of two members. On such appeal, there shall be no debate,
but the members making the appeal may briefly state their reasons therefor and
the President of Council shall have the same right.
(Ord. 2016-112. Passed 8-1-16.)
220.07 ABSENCE OF PRESIDENT OR PRESIDENT PRO TEM.
   In the absence of the President and the President Pro Tem of Council, the
next senior member of Council shall call the meeting to order and conduct the
meeting. If a quorum is present, the senior member conducting the meeting will
do so until the appearance of the President or President Pro Tem or until such
time as the meeting has concluded.
(Ord. 2016-112. Passed 8-1-16; Ord. 2019-027. Passed 3-4-19.)
220.08 ATTENDANCE OF OFFICIALS; REPORTS.
   The elective and appointive executive officials of the City may be requested
to attend regular and special meeting of Council, to answer such oral questions
as relate to the affairs of the City and to receive written requests for
information, investigation or enforcement action as may be directed to them by
any member of Council. If written requests are submitted, the official shall
make a report in writing to the requesting Council member at or before the next
regular meeting, if possible; if not, oral interim reports shall be made
monthly until the matter is completed or closed.
(Ord. 2016-112. Passed 8-1-16.)
220.09 ORDER OF BUSINESS.
   The order of business at meetings of Council shall be as follows:
   (a)   Call to order.
   (b)   Meditation and silence; Pledge to Flag.
   (c)   Roll call.
   (d)   Minutes.
   (e)   Communications.
   (f)   Delegations from the public.
   (g)   Reports of officials and boards.
   (h)   Reports of committees; introduction of ordinances and resolutions.
   (i)   All ordinances will be read by title only, except if a Council member
requests that a portion or all of the ordinance be read.
   (j)   First reading of ordinances and resolutions.
   (k)   Second reading of ordinances and resolutions.
   (l)   Third reading of ordinances and resolutions; dispositions.
   (m)   Old business.
   (n)   New business.
   (o)   President of Council remarks.
   (p)   Council members remarks.
   (q)   Mayor’s remarks.
   (r)   Adjournment.
      (Ord. 2016-112. Passed 8-1-16; Ord. 2020-112. Passed 12-31-20.)
220.10 AGENDA.
   The Clerk of Council shall prepare an agenda for each regular meeting of
Council and distribute a copy to each member prior to the meeting. This agenda
shall follow the form of the order of business set forth in Section
220.09 and shall ordinarily list the identity and purpose of appearances by
persons and delegations; the subject matter of petitions, remonstrances and
ordinances or resolutions to be introduced; the schedule of ordinances or
resolutions to be read on first, second and third readings; important subjects
of committee reports; and items of new business. All items to be placed on the
agenda shall be in the hands of the Clerk at least twenty-four hours prior to
the posting of the agenda as required by Ohio R.C. 121.22.
(Ord. 2016-112. Passed 8-1-16.)
220.11 RULES OF PROCEDURE.
   (a)   When an ordinance, resolution or motion is before Council, no other
motions are in order except motions:
      (1)   To adjourn the meeting;
      (2)   To table the matter (lay it aside until later);
      (3)   For the previous question (end discussion and vote), which must be
seconded;
      (4)   To postpone it to a definite future time;
      (5)   To refer it to committee;
      (6)   To amend it; or
      (7)   To postpone it for an indefinite time.
   (b)   The motions provided for in subsection (a) hereof shall have
precedence in the order listed. Motions (1), (2) and (3) shall be decided
without debate.
   (c)   A motion to reconsider a motion, ordinance or resolution which has
been passed must be made before adjournment of the session. A motion to
reconsider a motion, ordinance or regulation that has failed of passage must be
made not later than the next regular meeting. In either case, the motion must
be made by one who voted with the prevailing side.
   (d)   A motion to take a matter from the table is in order under new
business or under the business which was being transacted when the matter was
laid on the table. No debate except a brief explanation by the mover is
permitted.
   (e)   A motion to take a matter from a committee may be made by any member
of Council when a committee to which an ordinance or other matter has been
referred fails to report on it or to offer valid reasons for failure to report
on it. No debate except a brief explanation by the mover is permitted.
   (f)   All other matters of parliamentary procedure shall be determined by
the President in accordance with Robert's Rules of Order, Revised.
(Ord. 1964-9. Passed 3-2-64.)
220.12 PLAT ATTACHMENTS TO CERTAIN ORDINANCES.
   There is hereby adopted a policy that all requests to Council for
annexations, detachments, dedications or vacations must have the appropriate
plat attached prior to passage of the ordinance.
(Ord. 2016-112. Passed 8-1-16.)

222.01 PREPARATION.
   All ordinances and resolutions shall be prepared by the Law Director when
ordered by a majority vote of Council or of the Committee of the Whole, or when
requested in writing upon a form provided therefor, by the Mayor, any other
elected City official or the chairperson of any standing or special committee,
with the concurrence of a majority of the committee. All requests shall be in
the hands of the Clerk of Council at least three days prior to the Committee of
the Whole meeting that precedes the meeting at which the legislation is to be
introduced or considered. If not presented within that period, the request must
have the written endorsement thereon of the Mayor or the President of Council
and at least three members of Council. A copy of each ordinance and resolution
shall be provided to each member of Council at least twenty-four hours before
the time of the meeting at which the ordinance or resolution will be
introduced.
(Ord. 1964-9. Passed 3-2-64; Ord. 2020-007. Passed 3-2-20.)
222.02 INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE.
   Each ordinance and resolution requiring action shall be introduced and
sponsored by a member of Council who shall be fully informed as to the
provisions and purpose thereof, and which he or she shall, upon request,
explain to Council members. Ordinances and resolutions may be prepared,
numbered and introduced into Council either before or after the subject matter
has been referred to and reported on by a committee. Unless a request is made
by a member of Council to read the bylaw, ordinance, or resolution in part or
in full, the title of each bylaw, ordinance or resolution of Council shall be
read upon three separate and distinct days before submission for final passage.
This rule may be dispensed with by the affirmative vote of at least five
members of Council.
(1972 Code §123.02; Ord. 2020-007. Passed 3-2-20.)

234.01 TREASURY INVESTMENT BAORD; INVESTMENT OF FUNDS.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Treasury Investment Board consisting of
the Mayor, the Law Director and the Director of Finance.
(Ord. 1972-74. Passed 10-2-72.)
   (b)   Council hereby authorizes the Treasury Investment Board to invest
funds of the City, as provided for in Ohio R.C. 731.56 et seq.
   (c)   Such investments shall not be made at a price in excess of the current
market value of bonds or other interest-bearing obligations. Such bonds or
other interest- bearing obligations may be sold for cash and for a sum not less
than their current market price, in the manner prescribed in Ohio R.C. 731.57
et seq.

accordance with the provisions of Ohio R.C. 731.56 et seq.

234.02 QUALIFICATIONS OF FINANCE DIRECTOR.
   Council hereby establishes the qualification guidelines for the Finance
Director: Possession of a Bachelor's degree from an accredited college or
university in accounting or finance, or related field; experience in finance
and accounting at a supervisory or management level.
   The above qualifications shall be necessary in order for an individual to
run for the office of Finance Director if that individual does not possess a
degree in accounting or finance awarded by an accredited college or university.
(Ord. 1986-118. Passed 12-1-86; Ord. 2023-138. Passed 12-18-23.)
234.03 SANITARY SEWER ASSESSMENT INTEREST RATE.
   There is hereby established in assessment proceedings for a sanitary sewer
project a rate of interest to be determined in the following manner:
   (a)   If funds from the City are used to finance the project costs, and no
borrowed moneys are used, the individual benefitting from the assessment will
be charged one- half of the prime rate charged by large money center commercial
banks and reported in the Wall Street Journal Money Rates section as of the
date the resolution of necessity for the project becomes effective.
   (b)   If the City borrows the money to finance the sanitary sewer project,
the individual benefitting from the assessment will be charged at the same rate
of interest as that charged to the City on the borrowed funds.
      (Ord. 1987-143. Passed 11-2-87; Ord. 1988-47. Passed 5-2-88.)
234.04 TRANSFERS FROM LINE ITEM BUDGETS WITHIN FUNDS.
   Upon the concurrence of a department head, a department director, the Mayor
and the Finance Director, there is hereby granted the authority to transfer
funds from budget worksheet line items without the necessity of Finance
Committee approval, with the limitation that no transfer shall exceed one
thousand dollars ($1,000) and, further, that this section excludes
authorization for transfers involving salary accounts.
(Ord. 1999-037. Passed 3-1-99.)
234.05 UNCLAIMED MONEYS TRUST FUND.
   There is hereby established a trust fund entitled the Unclaimed Monies Trust
Fund, pursuant to the requirements of the Ohio Revised Code. The purpose of
said Fund will be for the deposit of stale-dated checks (over ninety days from
the date of issue), which checks shall be placed into the separate Trust Fund
for a period of five years, after which time the checks may then be placed into
the General Fund.
(Ord. 1995-46. Passed 4-3-95.)
234.06 INVESTMENT POLICY.
   There is hereby adopted in and for the City an Investment Policy, for
defining and authorizing investments of City funds, pursuant to the Ohio
Revised Code. Copies of such Policy, attached to original Ordinance 2000-044,
passed March 6, 2000, as Exhibit A, as amended, may be obtained, at cost, from
the Clerk of Council.
(Ord. 2000-044. Passed 3-6-00; Ord. 2000-129. Passed 9-5-00.)

more than one thousand dollars ($2,000.00).
(Ord. 2009-018. Passed 2-2-09; Ord. 2023-096. Passed 8-14-23.)
238.04 INDIGENT BURIALS.
   (a)   If a funeral home is contacted regarding an indigent burial, the City
of Ravenna Health Director of Public Service (Program Administrator
hereinafter) should be contacted immediately. Before any arrangements for
services are made, a member of the deceased’s family or a friend should
complete an Indigent Burial Application at the funeral home. Also, the funeral
home shall instruct the applicant to bring a signature identification such as a
driver’s license, and any documents regarding the deceased’s financial status.
However, if it is impossible to contact the Program Administrator prior to
making of arrangements for services, the funeral home may proceed and contact
the Program Administrator as soon as possible.
   (b)   The Program Administrator shall make a determination as to the
indigence through the following:
      (1)   The financial documents and information gathered by the funeral
home.
      (2)   If the deceased is a resident of a nursing home or assisted living
facility, the facility account balance needs to be verified and an inquiry
made, into who is paying the facility charges.
      (3)   The deceased must have been a Ravenna City resident.
      (4)   The resident must not own real estate.
   If the deceased is indigent, then the Program Administrator will notify the
funeral home to proceed with the funeral. He/she will also notify Maple Grove
Cemetery (Cemetery hereinafter) of said burial and forward to the Cemetery the
indigent burial request form. However, if there are sufficient funds from other
sources, no funds will be contributed by the City of Ravenna (City hereinafter)
and the funeral home and Cemetery will be notified immediately.
   (c)   The deceased must be buried at Maplegrove Union Cemetery in Ravenna,
Ohio. The City shall provide, at the grave of the deceased, a stone or concrete
marker on which the deceased’s name and age, if known, and the date of the
deceased’s death shall be inscribed. A marker may be donated by others.
   (d)   The City of Ravenna Indigent Burial Program (Program hereinafter) is
not supplemental. Funeral home personnel shall not ask for or accept any funds
above the amounts set forth herein. The amounts of $1,000.00 for the burial or
cremation of an adult; $500.00 for the burial of a child (1-18 years); $450.00
for the creation of a child (1-18 years) and $150.00 for a baby (fetus to one
year). This includes transportation of the deceased to Ravenna or any
unanticipated fees or charges. Furthermore, the funeral home and the City shall
make every effort to locate funds from other sources. The City may also file an
estate lien with the Probate Court if it feels funds may be available. If funds
are located, the City is paid back first and then the Cemetery. Any monies
reimbursed to the City will go to the General Fund.
   (e)   Upon completion of the funeral, the funeral home shall submit an
itemized bill to the Program Administrator containing the following
information:
      (1)   Name of deceased.
      (2)   Age of deceased.
      (3)   Place of burial.
      (4)   Services performed.
      (5)   Total cost of funeral.
      (6)   Amount received from other sources.
      (7)   Amount due from City.
   Said itemized bill shall not be submitted until thirty (30) days after the
services provided.
   (f)   Violations of the Program, at the discretion of the Law Director, can
result in suspension or permanent termination of the funeral home from the
Program.
   (g)   All indigent burials funded by the City shall be at Maple Grove
Cemetery in Ravenna, Ohio. The Cemetery shall notify the Program Administrator
of the date and time of the indigent burial so the City may send witnesses, if
desired. The Cemetery shall also give the City a copy of the Interment request
form, burial permit, itemization of the Cemetery’s usual and customary charges
for said burial (to include grave charge, opening/closing, foundation charge
for stone and any other charges incurred) and a signed statement from the
Cemetery Superintendent as proof of burial and billing for any future found
funds.
   (h)   All information on the application form shall be made in blue ink and
shall be filed with the original death certificate. A copy of this form will be
provided to the funeral home at no cost.
   (i)   If the person completing the application wishes to accept the cremains
of the deceased, they will complete a form for declination of services,
relieving the City of Ravenna and Maple Grove Union Cemetery from any future
actions or financial obligations.
(Ord. 2016-148. Passed 10-3-16.)

242.01 MUTUAL AID AGREEMENTS.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized to execute, on behalf of the City, such
agreements between the City and other municipalities as the Mayor believes to
be necessary for the purpose of providing mutual exchange of police facilities.
Such agreements shall remain in force for a period of three years. However, any
of the agreements may be terminated upon sixty days notice.
   Each agreement shall provide that no charge shall be made for the police
protection services rendered by each party to such agreement and that each
party shall assume the expense of the loss of or damage to its own equipment or
apparatus that may be incurred while in the jurisdiction of the other parties
to such agreement.
   Each agreement shall further provide that no liability shall arise to any
party to such agreement for injury to or death of any of its own police
officers while performing services in the jurisdiction of another municipality
as a result of such agreement.
(Ord. 1970-53. Passed 10-5-70.)
242.02 LAW ENFORCEMENT TRUST FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Law Enforcement Trust Fund to be
established by the Finance Director for the deposit of seventy-five percent of
all proceeds received by the Police Department from the disposal of forfeited
contraband by the Department. The remaining balance of twenty-five percent of
all proceeds received from the sale of forfeited contraband seized by the
Department shall be deposited in the Portage County Prosecutor's Law
Enforcement Trust Fund.
   (b)   It is hereby established that the proceeds distributed to the Law
Enforcement Trust Fund of the Police Department shall be allocated from the
Fund by Council only to the office of the Police Department pursuant to Ohio
R.C. 2933.43(D)(4).
(Ord. 1989-58. Passed 6-5-89.)
242.03 FEES FOR SERVICES.
   (a)   Upon presentation of a proper authorization or release, the following
fees shall be charged and collected for services rendered by the Police
Department when such services are rendered to other than law enforcement
officials of the City or County, agents of the Department of Justice of the
United States, any official agency of the United States, any military
organization of the United States or any police agency of any political
subdivision:
      Service                Fee
      (1)   Copy of an accident report      $ 4.00
      (2)   Copy of a crime report       4.00
      (3)   Copy of a miscellaneous report,
         per page             1.00
      (4)   Processing of a fingerprint card    5.00
      (5)   File check of a name             5.00
      (6)   Copy of a photograph           5.00
   (b)   The fees herein provided shall be paid into the General Fund of the
City.
(Ord. 1990-32. Passed 3-5-90.)
242.04 RENDERING OF SERVICES TO OTHER JURISDICTIONS WITHOUT A CONTRACT.
   (a)   The Director of Public Safety or, in his or her absence, the Chief of
Police, is hereby designated, in accordance with Ohio R.C. 737.041, to
authorize the rendering of police services to other subdivisions without a
contract, subject to review by the Mayor.
   (b)   Ohio R.C. Chapter 2744 (Political Subdivision Tort Liability), insofar
as it applies to the operation of police departments, shall apply to the City
of Ravenna and the sworn officers of its Police Department, when such members
are rendering police services pursuant to Ohio R.C. 737.041.
   (c)   Sworn officers of the City of Ravenna, while acting outside the City
limits of Ravenna, shall be entitled to participate in any pension fund
established by the City to the same extent as while acting within the City of
Ravenna. Such officers shall be entitled to all the rights provided in Ohio
R.C. 4123.01 through 4123.96 to the same extent as while performing services
within the City of Ravenna.
(Res. 1990-38. Passed 3-19-90.)
242.05 SALE OF RECOVERED PROPERTY.
   Stolen property or other property recovered by members of the police force
of the City and unclaimed for a period of ninety days shall be sold by the City
by a licensed auctioneer at public auction after giving due notice thereof by
advertisement, published once a week for three successive weeks in a newspaper
of general circulation in the County.
(Ord. 1990-92. Passed 7-12-90.)
242.06 AUXILIARY POLICE UNIT.
   (a)   Appointment of Members. There is hereby established within the
Department of Public Safety an Auxiliary Police Unit, the members of which
shall be appointed by the Director of Public Safety.
   (b)   Term of Service. Auxiliary police officers shall serve so long as the
Director of Public Safety may direct, or until a resignation submitted by any
member shall be accepted by the Director of Public Safety.
   (c)   Qualification of Members. The members of the Auxiliary Police Unit
shall not be under the age of twenty-one years at the time of their
appointment, and they shall meet such other requirements as are contained in
the rules and regulations provided for in subsection (e) hereof.
   (d)   Control of Unit. The Chief of Police shall be the commanding officer
of the Auxiliary Police Unit and shall have control of the assignment,
training, stationing and direction of work of such Unit. The Auxiliary Police
Unit will have all police powers, but shall perform only such police duties as
are assigned by the Chief of Police and shall act only when in the prescribed
uniform or portion of uniform. The Chief of Police shall prescribe the time and
place that such uniform or portion thereof shall be worn. Such auxiliary
members shall obey the chain of command of the Police Department and shall take
orders from all regular appointed members thereof.
   (e)   Rules and Regulations. The Director of Public Safety is authorized to
prescribe the rules and regulations for the organization, administration,
conduct and control of the Auxiliary Police Unit.
   (f)   Uniform. The Director of Public Safety is authorized to prescribe, by
the rules and regulations, the type of uniform or part thereof which shall be
worn by members of the Auxiliary Police Unit.
   (g)   Service on Voluntary Basis; Compensation. All services performed by
auxiliary policemen shall be on a voluntary basis and within the City. The
auxiliary police officers will be included in a worker's compensation program.
However, they will receive no further compensation for their services.
   (h)   Nonliability. This section is hereby declared to be enacted for the
protection of the public peace, health, property, safety and general welfare,
and neither the City nor any agent or representative thereof, an officer
appointed under the provisions of this section or any individual, firm,
partnership, corporation or the receiver or trustees or any other agent
thereof, who, in good faith, executes any executive order, rule or regulation
promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this section, shall be liable for
injury or damage sustained to any person or property as the direct or proximate
result of such action.
(Ord. 1979-75. Passed 5-23-79.)
242.07 PROMOTIONAL TEST FOR SERGEANT.
   There is hereby established a requirement for promotional tests, whereby a
police officer taking a promotional test for Sergeant must have a minimum of
three years of full-time service as police officer with any qualified local,
State or Federal law enforcement agency.
(Ord. 2000-062. Passed 7-5-00.)
242.08 UNIFORM AND CLOTHING ALLOWANCE.
   (a)   The Chief of Police and Assistant Chief of Police shall receive a
uniform allowance for the purchase of equipment and additional civilian
clothing and dry cleaning reimbursement authorized pursuant to Section 305.01
of Rules and Regulations of the Ravenna City Police Department, worn while on
duty up to the sum of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) per year. Each
part-time police officer shall receive four hundred fifty dollars ($450.00) per
year in clothing and equipment/dry cleaning reimbursement. Each part-time radio
dispatch clerk and part-time parking enforcement officer, shall receive a three
hundred fifty dollar ($350.00) per year uniform reimbursement. New non-union
employees shall receive the full allowance in the first year of service and the
following year will be prorated.
   (b)   In December, the Police Chief and Assistant Chief of Police employed
as of December first of each year shall be provided a four hundred fifty
dollars ($450.00) uniform maintenance allowance. This payment shall only be
made to those employees who are in full-time employment with the City and on a
prorated share for those completed months that the employee worked during that
calendar year. This payment shall be made directly to the employee and be used
for uniform maintenance and acquisition.
(Ord. 2016-048. Passed 4-4-16; Ord. 2024-138. Passed 12-2-24.)
242.09 FITNESS INCENTIVE PROGRAM.
   (a)   TThe Chief of Police, Assistant Chief of Police, and all part-time
patrol officers of the Police Department shall be eligible to participate in
the Fitness Incentive Program. Each employee who passes all phases of the
fitness test, which will be given twice per year as established by the
employer, shall be granted a bonus according to the established schedule. The
fitness test is voluntary.
   (b)   To qualify for a bonus, an employee must achieve a three or better
rating on each phase of the fitness test. The average score of the two tests
shall be used to determine the bonus, if any. A test score of two or less in
any phase of the semi-annual scheduled fitness dates shall disqualify employees
from receiving any bonus granted under this section. All participants must
complete the twelve minute run unless the employee has a signed medical excuse
approved by the Chief of Police. The Chief of Police may allow the employee to
take a bicycle test where the employee shall only receive a maximum bonus of
two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) after passing the other phases of the
fitness test.
 
Fitness Rating Bonus Pay
3              $500.00
4              $750.00
5              $1,000.00
Bicycle Use    $250.00
 
(Ord. 2016-048. Passed 4-4-16; Ord. 2024-138. Passed 12-2-24.)

244.01 POWERS AND DUTIES OF FIRE CHIEF.
   The Fire Chief shall have sole command at all fires over all members of the
Fire Department and all persons in attendance, and he or she shall have police
powers as an ex officio police officer. He or she shall examine the condition
of all apparatus, buildings and fixtures of the Fire Department and see that
the same are kept and maintained in good condition and that all rules and
regulations of the Department are enforced and observed by the members of the
Department and all other persons.
(1972 Code §143.01)
244.02 MEMBER STATUS OF VOLUNTEERS.
   All the regular volunteer members of the Fire Department as of February 7,
1955, are hereby declared to be full-fledged members of the Fire Department and
under the classified civil service with full civil service rights of tenure and
promotion.
(Ord. 1955-6. Passed 2-7-55.)
244.03 APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS.
   All future vacancies among volunteer members shall be filled by appointment
of the Mayor after certification to him or her of an eligible list by the Civil
Service Commission.
(Ord. 1955-6. Passed 2-7-55.)
244.04 EXTRA DUTY.
   When, in the opinion of the Fire Chief, it is necessary for the preservation
of life or property in the City, the Fire Chief may call out for active duty
any regular full-time fire- fighter and truck driver who is off duty at that
time.
(Ord. 1951-51. Passed 5-7-51.)
244.05 EMERGENCY AMBULANCE SERVICE SYSTEM.
   (a)   Establishment. There is hereby established an emergency ambulance
service system within the Fire Department.
      (1)   The Fire Chief, or his or her designee, shall determine under the
particular circumstances of each case whether or not emergency ambulance
service shall be provided outside the corporate limits of the City.
      (2)   The individual provided with emergency ambulance service shall be
transported to Robinson Memorial Hospital. An alternative facility may be
determined by the Fire Chief, or his or her designee, due to unusual
circumstances.
   (b)   Equipment. Each ambulance shall be equipped with the minimal equipment
as stated by the American College of Surgeons, including, but not limited to,
the following:
      (1)   One extra set of clean linen;
      (2)   One crash pouch;
      (3)   Two basket-type leg splints;
      (4)   Two basket-type arm splints;
      (5)   Mechanical means of resuscitation and a tank of oxygen with a
reduction gauge;
      (6)   Mechanical means of aspiration or suction with a set of catheters
for adults and children;
      (7)   A back board for use in cardiac resuscitation;
      (8)   A full-length back board for back injuries;
      (9)   Two pneumatic arm splints and two pneumatic leg splints;
      (10)   Oropharyngeal airways in adult, child and infant sizes;
      (11)   Maternity kits, including umbilical tape or clamps, baby blankets,
scissors and a bulb syringe;
      (12)   Two pairs of sterile rubber gloves;
      (13)   Tongue depressors;
      (14)   Ammonia;
      (15)   Three tourniquets;
      (16)   Five triangle bandages;
      (17)   Sufficient bandages to take care of two or more patients;
      (18)   A first-aid kit containing gauze squares, tape, scissors and
roller bandages;
      (19)   A one-hand operated bag-mask ventilation unit with adult and child
size masks. Clear masks are preferable. Valves shall operate in cold weather
and the unit shall be capable of use with an oxygen supply;
      (20)   One portable oxygen equipment with adequate tubing and semi-open
valveless, transparent masks in adult, child and infant sizes. A portable unit
of 300-liter capacity located near a door for ready use outside the vehicle
should be equipped with a yoke, pressure gauge, flowmeter (not gravity
dependent), delivery tube and oxygen mask. The unit should be capable of
delivering an oxygen flow of at least ten liters per minute. An extra 300-liter
capacity cylinder should be available. Oxygen masks with or without bags should
be semi-opened, valveless, transparent, disposable or easy to clean and
decontaminate, and in sizes for adults, children and infants;
      (21)   Three mouth gags, either commercial or made of three tongue blades
taped together and padded;
      (22)   Six sterile universal dressings, approximately ten inches by
thirty inches, compactly folded and packaged in convenient size;
      (23)   Twenty-four sterile gauze pads, minimum four inches by four
inches;
      (24)   Twelve rolls of soft roller self-adhering type bandages, two,
three, four and six inches by five yard combinations. No less than two rolls of
any size;
      (25)   One roll of aluminum foil, eighteen inches by twenty-five feet,
sterilized and wrapped, heavy plastic is not acceptable;
      (26)   Two rolls of plain adhesive tape, three inches wide;
      (27)   Two sterile burn sheets; ordinary bed sheets, wrapped, sterilized
and packaged in plastic bags may be used;
      (28)   One hinged half-ringed lower extremity traction splint (ring nine
inches in diameter, overall length of splint forty-three inches) with limb
support and slings, padded ankle hitch, and traction strap;
      (29)   Two or more padded boards, four and one-half feet long by three
inches wide, and two or more similarly padded boards, three feet long, of
material comparable to four-ply wood for coaptation splint of leg or thigh;
      (30)   Two or more fifteen-inch by three-inch padded wooden splints for
fractures of the forearm. (By local option, similar splints of cardboard,
plastic, wire ladder or canvas slotted lace-on may be carried in place of the
above thirty-six inch and fifteen-inch boards.);
      (31)   One set of uncomplicated inflatable splints consisting of two full
arm and two full leg splints;
      (32)   A short extraction board with two nine-foot straps and long spine
boards with three straps and a foot plate. One short board and one long board
of the following dimensions and construction are required;
         A.   Minor variations in dimensions may be allowed if functional
capabilities are not compromised;
         B.   Two straps of two-inch belting at least nine feet long and
equipped with slip-through friction catches are required;
      (33)   Twelve triangular bandages;
      (34)   One poison kit. Minimum contents:
         A.   Syrup of Ipecac, four ounces
         B.   One liter of drinking water (paragraph (b)(36) hereof shall
qualify)
         C.   Activated charcoal, one packet
         D.   Measuring device, one teaspoon
         E.   Snakebite kits in areas where this need exists;
      (35)   One portable blood pressure manometer, cuff and stethoscope;
      (36)   One-half gallon of distilled water, stored in an unbreakable
container;
      (37)   Two 500 cc bags of sterile saline (IV fluids) for protruding
abdominal wounds;
      (38)   Fire extinguisher - drypowder type BC - # size - mounted in the
patient compartment;
      (39)   Flashlight (minimum 2 cell (size C)). Recommended stand-up lantern
type with dry-cell battery;
      (40)   Spotlight or floodlight; and
      (41)   Litter(s), with knee and chest area restraints on each. Minimum of
two. Each ambulance shall be provided with one wheeled litter seventy-six
inches long and twenty-three inches wide. A second litter is required. This may
be a folding or adjustable litter twenty-three inches wide, or a long spine
board eighteen inches by seventy-two inches.
   (c)   Reports.
      (1)   The Fire Chief shall maintain, or cause to be maintained, a log
book which shall contain the following:
         A.   The time the call was received;
         B.   The time the emergency ambulance was dispatched;
         C.   The arrival time at the scene;
         D.   The nature of the call;
         E.   The arrival time at the hospital;
         F.   The name of the hospital;
         G.   The time the call was completed;
         H.   The name and address of the person transported; and
         I.   The names of the driver and the attendant.
      (2)   The Fire Chief shall, at the completion of each emergency ambulance
run, have completed, in detail by the EMT, a report of the situation for
delivery to the Finance Director the following morning for purposes of billing
the patient or and/or the parents or guardian in the case of minors.
      (3)   The Fire Chief shall submit to Council and the Mayor a monthly
report of all activity as it shall pertain to the emergency ambulance service.
The first report shall be due September 1, 1980.
         (Ord. 1980-89. Passed 7-28-80.)
   (d)   Charges. Charges for emergency ambulance service shall be made as
follows:
Type of Trip                                                                            Charge
      (1)   All other services, as follows:                                     
         A.   Basic life support                                            650.00
         B.   Advanced life support 1                                       750.00
         C.   Advanced life support 2                                       825.00
         D.   Non-transport                                                 75.00
      (2)   Mileage (per mile)                                                 12.00
      (3)   Exam, vitals, patient history, no transport/ treatment (refused by 50.00nt
or proper authority)
 
      (4)   Any services rendered to a covered employee and/or dependent of the
City shall not be billed to said employee.
      (5)   The Finance Director is hereby authorized to set up payment plans
with persons unable to pay their full bill at one time. The minimum payment to
be accepted is twenty dollars ($20.00) per month. The exact make up and terms
of such payment plans is left to the discretion of the Finance Director.
(Ord. 1998-054. Passed 2-2-98; Ord. 2002-068. Passed 5-6-02; Ord. 2007- 166.
Passed 1-7-08; Ord. 2013-114. Passed 9-3-13; Ord. 2023-003. Passed 1-3-23.)
   (e)   Liability Insurance. The Finance Director shall obtain liability
insurance with the insurance company presently providing coverage for the City,
providing:
      (1)   Coverage for injury to or death of an individual in accidents
resulting from any cause for which the driver or attendants of such emergency
ambulance would be liable on account of liability imposed on him or her by law.
      (2)   Against damage to the property of another, including personal
property under like circumstances in such sums and under such terms as may be
required by statute.
         (Ord. 1980-89. Passed 7-28-80.)
244.055 NON-EMERGENCY AMBULANCE SERVICE.
   (a)   There is hereby established a non-emergency ambulance service within
the Fire Department of the City.
   (b)   Each ambulance shall be equipped as an advanced life support vehicle.
   (c)   The charge for each non-emergency ambulance service shall be four
hundred seventy-five dollars ($475.00), plus seven dollars ($7.00) per loaded
mile. The charges set forth herein shall be billed to the person for whom
services are provided.
   (d)   Proper authorization shall be provided at the time of scheduling.
   (e)   All funds collected for non-emergency ambulance service shall be
deposited to the General Fund.
(Ord. 1998-161. Passed 8-3-98.)
   (f)   The Finance Director is hereby authorized to create accounts and
appropriate funds for non-emergency transport operations.
(Ord. 1998-150. Passed 7-6-98.)

244.08 UNIFORM ALLOWANCE.
   (a)   The Fire Chief shall receive a uniform allowance for the purchase of
essential, special clothing worn while on duty up to the sum of seven hundred
dollars ($700.00) per year. Each part-time firefighter shall receive two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per year in clothing and equipment/dry cleaning
reimbursement. New non-union employees shall receive the full allowance in the
first year of service and the following year will be pro-rated.
   (b)   In December, the Fire Chief employed as of December first of each year
shall be provided a six hundred dollars ($600.00) uniform maintenance
allowance. This payment shall only be made to those employees who are in full-
time employment with the City and on a prorated share for those completed
months that the employee worked during that calendar year. This payment shall
be made directly to the employee and be used for uniform maintenance and
acquisition.
   (c)   Turn-out gear such as helmets, boots, raincoats and EMT equipment,
will be paid for by the City. All items are to remain the property of the City
upon termination of the employee. Such articles shall be purchased as needed
only upon the written authorization of the Fire Chief and Mayor.
(Ord. 2000-163. Passed 12-4-00; Ord. 2006-034. Passed 3-6-06; Ord. 2006-213.
Passed 12-29-06; Ord. 2024-138. Passed 12-2-24.)
244.09 MEETINGS OR DRILLS; TRAINING SESSIONS; COMPENSATION.
   The Fire Chief shall be compensated for attendance at monthly meetings or
drills at the rate of thirty dollars ($30.00) per meeting or drill called by
him or her. Part-time fire-fighters shall be compensated for attendance at
training sessions at the rate of fourteen dollars ($14.00) per session.
(Ord. 2000-163. Passed 12-4-00.)
244.10 COMPENSATION.
   All personnel in the Fire Department shall be paid from the General Fund and
the EMS Fund.
(Ord. 2000-163. Passed 12-4-00.)
